tit.cmt: 定訳ではないので、日本語読みにしました。

sen.j: 名主（みょうしゅ）は、日本の古代末期から中世日本にかけて、国衙領・荘園領主から名田の経営を請け負った。
sen.e: Village headmen called "myoshu" were a class of people who were commissioned to manage the cultivation of farmland called "myoden" by governors of government territories and manorial lords during the late Ancient period and the Middle Ages in Japan.

Village headmen called "myoshu" were a class of people who were commissioned to manage the cultivation of farmland called "myoden" by governors of government territories and manorial lords during the late Ancient Period and the Middle Ages in Japan.

Myoshu (village headmen) were a class of people who were commissioned to manage the cultivation of farmland called myoden by lords of Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office) and manors during the late Ancient period and the Middle Ages in Japan.

sen.j: それとともに、領主への貢納（年貢・公事・夫役）の責務を担った階層である。
sen.e: They were also obligated to collect tribute and taxes (taxes in kind, public duties and labor services) for territorial rulers.
They were also obligated to collect tribute and taxes (taxes in kind, public duties and labor services) for territorial rulers.
They were also obligated to collect tribute and taxes (taxes in kind, public duties and labor services) for territorial rulers.

sen.j: 近世（江戸時代）において、名主（なぬし）は地方三役の呼び名の一つとなった。
sen.e: In the early modern age (Edo period), village headmen were called "nanushi," which was one of the three official positions of a village community.
In the early modern age, and specifically the Edo Period, village headmen were called "nanushi," which was one of the three official positions of a village community.
In the early modern age, and specifically the Edo period, village headmen were called nanushi, which was one of the three official positions of a provincial community.

sen.j: （詳細は庄屋を参照。）
sen.e: (For details, see the article about Shoya (village headman in the Edo period).)
For details, see the article about Shoya (village headman in the Edo period).
(For details, see the article about Shoya [village headman in the Edo period]).
sen.cmt: かっこを補足しました。

tit.cmt: More natural as it is a process rather than a marked period.

sen.j: 日本では、8世紀初頭以来、律令に基づいた土地支配・租税収取が政府によって行われてきた。
sen.e: In Japan, land had been controlled by the government under the ritsuryo legal codes in order to collect land taxes since the early 8th century,
In Japan, land had been controlled by the government under the ritsuryo legal codes in order to collect land taxes since the early 8th century.
In Japan, land had been controlled by the government under the ritsuryo legal codes in order to collect land taxes since the early eighth century.
sen.cmt: スペルアウトしました。

sen.j: しかし、9世紀に入ると支配・収取から逃れるために百姓たちの逃亡・浮浪が顕著となっていき、律令制支配・収取は大きな転換が迫られていた。
sen.e: In the 9th century, however, farmers began to flee from their villages and became vagrants in increasing numbers in order to escape from government control and taxation, thereby calling for a major change in the system of administration and taxation based on the ancient ritsuryo legal codes.

In the 9th century, however, farmers began to flee from their villages and became vagrants in increasing numbers in order to escape government control and taxation, thereby necessitating a major change in the system of administration and taxation based on the ancient ritsuryo legal codes.

In the ninth century, however, farmers began to flee from their villages and became vagrants in increasing numbers in order to escape government control and taxation, thereby necessitating a major change in the system of administration and taxation based on the ancient ritsuryo legal codes.
sen.cmt: スペルアウトしました。

sen.j: 9世紀後期～10世紀にかけて、政府は従前から実施してきた人別支配を改め、収取の対象となる土地そのものに対する支配・収取体制を確立していった。
sen.e: From the late 9th to 10th century, the government gradually replaced the traditional system of direct rule over individual farmers by a system of rule and taxation of land, which was the very source of taxation.

From the late 9th to 10th century, the government gradually replaced the traditional system of direct rule over individual farmers with a system of rule and taxation of land, which became the source of taxation.

From the late 9th to 10th century, the government gradually replaced the traditional system of direct rule over individual farmers with a system of rule and taxation of land, which became the source of taxation.

sen.j: それは、国衙が支配する土地（公田）を名田（みょうでん）という単位に再編し、当時、経済力をつけていた田堵と呼ばれる富豪層（有力百姓層）に名田経営を請け負わせることで、租税収入を確保する体制（名体制という。）であった。
sen.e: The government established the new system of rule (known as the myo system) aimed at ensuring the collection of tax revenues by reorganizing the government land (public farmland) into units called "myoden" and by hiring influential farmers called "tato," who had accumulated considerable wealth during the period, to manage myoden.

The government established the new system of rule (known as the myo system) aimed at ensuring the collection of tax revenues by reorganizing government land (public farmland) into units called "myoden" and by hiring influential farmers called "tato," who had accumulated considerable wealth during the period, to manage the myoden.

The government established the system of rule (known as myo taisei) aimed at ensuring the collection of tax revenues by reorganizing government land (public farmland) into units called myoden and by hiring influential farmers called tato, who had accumulated considerable wealth during the period, to manage the myoden.

sen.j: また、田堵の側にとっても、権利関係が不安定なままで田地経営を行うよりも、国司の公認を得て、安定した権利関係の上で田地を経営することには大きなメリットがあった。
sen.e: The new system, which gave tato farmers the official right to cultivate land with the acknowledgement of territorial governors, also brought considerable advantages to these farmers, who had had to maintain their land in unstable social relationships.

The new system, which gave tato farmers the official right to cultivate land with the acknowledgement of territorial governors, also brought considerable advantages to these farmers, who had had to maintain their land in unstable social relationships.

The system, which gave tato farmers the official right to cultivate land with the acknowledgement of territorial governors, also brought considerable advantages to these farmers, who had had to maintain their land in unstable social relationships.

sen.j: こうして名田を経営するようになった田堵は、負名または田堵負名などと呼ばれた。
sen.e: These tato farmers who cultivated myoden land were called "fumyo" (subcontractors) or "tato fumyo."
These tato farmers who cultivated myoden land were called "fumyo" (subcontractors) or "tato fumyo."
These tato farmers who cultivated myoden land were called fumyo (subcontractors) or tato fumyo.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: その後、荘園にも名田化が波及すると、田堵は荘園内の名田経営も請け負うようになった。
sen.e: As the myoden system was subsequently introduced into manors, tato farmers were commissioned to manage the cultivation of myoden land within manors as well.
As the myoden system was subsequently introduced into manors, tato farmers were commissioned to manage the cultivation of myoden land within manors as well.
As the myoden system was subsequently introduced into manors, tato farmers were commissioned to manage the cultivation of myoden land within manors as well.

sen.j: 田堵負名には、在地領主の支配下で名田経営する者もいたが、田堵負名自身が在地領主として現地支配・管理する者も多かった。
sen.e: Although some of these tato fumyo farmers managed myoden land under the rule of local territorial lords, many of them ruled land by themselves as territorial lords.
Although some of these tato fumyo farmers managed myoden land under the rule of local territorial lords, many of them ruled land as territorial lords themselves.
Although some of these tato fumyo farmers managed myoden land under the rule of local territorial lords, many of them ruled land as territorial lords themselves.

sen.j: そして、田堵負名は、公領にあっては在庁官人や郡司・郷司・保司などとして国司の下に、荘園にあっては下司・公文などの荘官として領主の下に、それぞれ編成されていった。
sen.e: Tato fumyo farmers were gradually placed under the rule of territorial governors as local government officers called "gunji," "goji" or "hoji" in government territories, and under the rule of manorial lords in manors as their retainers called "geshi" or "kumon."

Tato fumyo farmers were gradually placed under the rule of territorial governors in the role of local government officers called "gunji," "goji" or "hoji" within government territories, and under the rule of manorial lords in manors as their retainers called "geshi" or "kumon."

Tato fumyo farmers were gradually placed under the rule of territorial governors in the role of local government officers called gunji, goji or hoji within government territories, and under the rule of manorial lords in manors as their retainers called geshi or kumon.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: 国司や領主などの支配層は、田堵負名による名田経営を強化するために、現地での支配権・管理権を次第に付与していった。
sen.e: The ruling class, including territorial governors and manorial lords, granted tato farmers various rights to rule and manage land in villages in order to strengthen the myoden system supported by these farmers.

The ruling class, including territorial governors and manorial lords, granted tato farmers various rights to rule and manage land in villages in order to strengthen the myoden system supported by these farmers.

The ruling class, including territorial governors and manorial lords, granted tato farmers various rights to rule and manage land in villages in order to strengthen the myoden system supported by these farmers.

sen.j: こうして与えられた支配権・管理権は一様ではなく、名田の規模・態様によってさまざまな形態をとっていたが、いずれにせよ田堵負名は、国司・領主に認められた権限を背景に、現地において百姓らへの支配を強めていったのである。
sen.e: Although these rights to rule and manage land varied greatly depending on the size and configuration of myoden land, tato fumyo farmers succeeded in strengthening their control over peasants in many villages by using the authority recognized by their own rulers.

Although these rights to rule and manage land varied greatly depending on the size and arrangement of myoden land, tato fumyo farmers succeeded in strengthening their control over peasants in many villages by using the authority recognized by their own rulers.

Although these rights to rule and manage land varied greatly depending on the size and arrangement of myoden land, tato fumyo farmers succeeded in strengthening their control over peasants in many villages by using the authority recognized by their own rulers.

sen.j: 11世紀後期～12世紀ごろになると、田堵負名層は名主（みょうしゅ）と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: During the late 11th and 12th centuries, tato fumyo farmers came to be known as "myoshu."
During the late 11th and 12th centuries, tato fumyo farmers came to be known as "myoshu."
During the late 11th and 12th centuries, tato fumyo farmers came to be known as myoshu.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: この時期、荘園や公領を支配・収取の単位とする体制、すなわち荘園公領制が確立したが、名主は荘園公領制の基盤を支える階層といえた。
sen.e: A system composed of manors and government territories as basic units of administration and taxation, known as the manorial public territory system (called "shoen-koryo-sei" in Japanese), was established during this period, with myoshu farmers forming the basis of the system.

A system composed of manors and government territories as basic units of administration and taxation, known as the manorial public territory system (called "shoen-koryo-sei" in Japanese), was established during this period, with myoshu farmers forming the basis of the system.

A system composed of manors and government territories as basic units of administration and taxation, known as the manorial public territory system (called shoen koryo sei in Japanese), was established during this period, with myoshu farmers forming the basis of the system.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 荘園公領制の進展の中で、国司・荘園領主から認められた名田に対する諸権利は、名主職（みょうしゅしき）として確立していった。
sen.e: As the manorial public territory system developed, various rights over myoden land were officially acknowledged by territorial governors and manorial lords as myoshu rights ("myoshu shiki" in Japanese).

As the manorial public territory system developed, various rights over myoden land were officially acknowledged by territorial governors and manorial lords as myoshu rights ("myoshu shiki" in Japanese).
As the manorial public territory system developed, various rights over myoden land were officially acknowledged by territorial governors and manorial lords as myoshushiki (myoshu rights).
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせ、かっこ内を英訳にしました。

sen.j: 名田において、名主は百姓らから年貢・公事・夫役を徴収し、国司や荘園領主へ納入する義務を負っていた。
sen.e: In the myoden system, myoshu were obligated to collect taxes (taxes in kind, public duties and labor services) from peasants for territorial governors or manorial lords.
In the myoden system, myoshu were obligated to collect taxes (taxes in kind, public duties and labor services) from peasants for territorial governors or manorial lords.
In the myoden system, myoshu were obligated to collect taxes (taxes in kind, public duties and labor services) from peasants for territorial governors or manorial lords.

sen.j: また、名主は、百姓から徴収した中から加地子を中間得分として自らの収入としていた。
sen.e: Myoshu also collected supplementary taxes (called "kajishi" in Japanese) from peasants as their own commissions.
Myoshu also collected supplementary taxes (called "kajishi" in Japanese) from peasants as their own income.
Myoshu also collected kajishi (supplementary taxes) from peasants as their own income.
sen.cmt: かっこ内を英訳にしました。

sen.j: さらに下人・所従と呼ばれる隷属民を使役して、国司・領主から承認された給田・免田や自らの屋敷周辺に設定した私的な田地を耕作させる者もおり、その場合、収穫物は全て名主の収入となった。
sen.e: Some of them even used unfree peasants called "genin" or "shoju" to cultivate tax-exempt land granted by territorial governors and manorial lords or private farmland around their houses, in which case all taxes collected became their own earnings.

Some of them even used unfree peasants called "genin" or "shoju" to cultivate tax-exempt land granted by the territorial governors and manorial lords or private farmland around their houses, in which case all taxes collected became their own earnings.

Some of them even used unfree peasants called genin or shoju to cultivate tax-exempt land granted by the territorial governors and manorial lords or private farmland around their houses, in which case all taxes collected became their own earnings.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: 名主の立場には二面性があった。
sen.e: Myoshu had two different aspects.
The position of myoshu had two different aspects.
The position of myoshu had two different aspects.

sen.j: 国司・荘園領主などの支配層から見れば、名主は支配される側、すなわち被支配者だったが、一般百姓らから見れば名主は現地における支配者だった。
sen.e: From the viewpoint of the ruling class, including territorial governors and manorial lords, they were part of the ruled class, while from the viewpoint of ordinary peasants, they were themselves rulers in village communities.

From the viewpoint of the ruling class, including territorial governors and manorial lords, they were part of the ruled class, while from the viewpoint of ordinary peasants, they were themselves rulers in village communities.

From the viewpoint of the ruling class, including territorial governors and manorial lords, they were part of the ruled class, while from the viewpoint of ordinary peasants, they were themselves rulers in village communities.

sen.j: このように、名主の性格は一概に説明できるものではなく、名田を経営した階層と広義に解釈されている。
sen.e: Thus, the myoshu class defies simple characterization and is interpreted broadly as a class of farmers who managed the cultivation of myoden land.
Thus, the myoshu class defies simple characterization and is interpreted broadly as a class of farmers who managed the cultivation of myoden land.
Thus, the myoshu class defies simple characterization and is interpreted broadly as a class of farmers who managed the cultivation of myoden land.

sen.j: また、名主は、畿内周辺では農業経営に携わる有力百姓としての性格が強かったが、その他の地域では豪族的な者もおり、特に関東では武士の郎党的な者も多かった。
sen.e: In Kinai (areas around Kyoto and Osaka), myoshu were mostly influential farmers who were themselves engaged in farming, but in other areas, especially in eastern regions, retainers of warrior class were often included among myoshu.

In Kinai (areas around Kyoto and Osaka), myoshu were mostly influential farmers who were themselves engaged in farming, but in other areas, especially in eastern regions, retainers of warrior class were often included among myoshu.

In Kinai (areas around Kyoto and Osaka), myoshu were mostly influential farmers who were themselves engaged in farming, but in other areas, especially in Kanto regions (region including Tokyo), retainers of warrior class were often included among myoshu.

sen.j: 12世紀末に鎌倉幕府が登場すると、特に東国の名主の中には、幕府に帰参して御家人となり、地頭に補任される者も現れた。
sen.e: When the Kamakura shogunate government came to power toward the end of the 12th century, some myoshu farmers, especially those in eastern regions, gained a position in the shogunate government and became samurai retainers (called "gokenin") to be appointed as local landlord called "jito."

When the Kamakura shogunate government came to power toward the end of the 12th century, some myoshu farmers, especially those in eastern regions, gained positions in the shogunate government and became samurai retainers (called "gokenin") or were appointed as local landlord called "jito."

When the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) came to power toward the end of the 12th century, some myoshu farmers, especially those in eastern regions, gained positions in the shogunate government and became gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods) or were appointed as jito (local landlord).
sen.cmt: かっこ内を英訳にしました。

tit.j: 名主職の売券の例（室町期）
tit.e: An example of a deed of sale of myoshu rights (Muromachi period)
An example of a deed of sale of myoshu rights (Muromachi Period)
An example of a deed of sale of myoshu rights (Muromachi Period)

sen.j: 「僧承瑾名主職売券」
sen.e: Deed of sale of the myoshu rights of Shokin, a Buddhist monk
sen.cmt: 承瑾(Shokin)の読み方が不明です。
sen.e: Deed of sale of the myoshu rights of Shokin, a Buddhist monk
Deed of sale of the myoshu rights of Shokin (承瑾), a Buddhist monk'
sen.cmt: 読み不明の漢字とクォーテーションを補足しました。

sen.j: 売渡申時久名之田畠名主職事
sen.e: I hereby certify that I sold my myoshu rights over the land in Tokihisa Myo village.
I hereby certify that I sold my myoshu rights over the land in Tokihisa Myo village.
I hereby certify that I sold my myoshu rights over the land in Tokihisa Myo village.

sen.j: 合壱町参段者。
sen.e: The land sold covers a total area of 1 cho and 3 tan (approximately 13,000 square meters).
The land sold covers a total area of 1 cho and 3 tan (approximately 13,000 square meters).
The land sold covers a total area of 1 cho and 3 tan (approximately 13,000 square meters).

sen.j: 此外屋敷有之。
sen.e: A house is also included as part of the property.
A house is also included as part of the property.
A house is also included as part of the property.

sen.j: 在所山城国葛野郡近衛殿御領内梅津庄也。
sen.e: The land is located in Umezu-sho in Lord Konoe's territory, in Kadonono-kori of Yamashiro Province.
sen.cmt: http://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/葛野郡 によれば、「葛野郡」は、[かどののこうり」と読むのが正しいようです。
sen.e: The land is located in Umezu-sho in Lord Konoe's territory, in Kadonono-kori in Yamashiro Province.
The land is located in Umezu-sho in Lord Konoe's territory, in Kadono no kori in Yamashiro Province.

sen.j: 目録並公事物等注文者別紙有之。
sen.e: Items to be sold and taxes collected from the land are listed in the attached document.
Items to be sold and taxes collected from the land are listed in the attached document.
Items to be sold and taxes collected from the land are listed in the attached document.

sen.j: 右件田畠名主職者、僧承瑾先祖相伝之地也。
sen.e: Myoshu rights over the above land were inherited by Shokin, a Buddhist monk, from his ancestors.
Myoshu rights over the above land were inherited by Shokin, a Buddhist monk, from his ancestors.
Myoshu rights over the above land were inherited by Shokin, a Buddhist monk, from his ancestors.

sen.j: 雖然依有要用、直銭肆拾壱貫文仁限永代相副本券等所売渡申沙弥道忍仁実正也。
sen.e: However, due to circumstances beyond my control, I hereby sell my property rights for ever for cash in the amount of 41 kan-mon.
However, due to circumstances beyond my control, I hereby sell my property rights forever for the sum of 41 kan-mon.
However, due to circumstances beyond my control, I hereby sell my property rights forever for the sum of 41 kan-mon.

sen.j: 若於此名主職仁違犯煩申輩出来時者、以本銭一陪可弁沙汰申候。
sen.e: If any third party should file complaints about this sale of myoshu rights in the future, I hereby agree to negotiate with the third party to refund the payment in full.
If any third party should file complaints about this sale of myoshu rights in the future, I hereby agree to negotiate with the third party to refund the payment in full.
If any third party should file complaints about this sale of myoshu rights in the future, I hereby agree to negotiate with the third party to refund the payment in full.

sen.j: 尚〃無沙汰之時者、請人相共可致其明候。
sen.e: If the negotiation should fail, I will work together with my guarantors to settle all problems.
If any such negotiation should fail, I will work together with my guarantors to settle all problems.
If any such negotiation should fail, I will work together with my guarantors to settle all problems.

sen.j: 其時更一言子細不可申候。
sen.e: I will fulfill my obligation without making any further complaint.
I will fulfill my obligation without making any further complaint.
I will fulfill my obligation without making any further complaint.

sen.j: 仍為後日売券之状如件。
sen.e: I hereby certify that the above sale was properly concluded.
I hereby certify that the above sale was properly concluded.
I hereby certify that the above sale was properly concluded.

sen.j: 応永廿四年丁酉弐月九日 売主承瑾（花押）
sen.e: March 6, 1417 Seller: Shokin (seal)
March 6, 1417 Seller: Shokin (seal)
March 6, 1417 Seller: Shokin (seal)

sen.j: 但請人六ヶ年間也 相共請人 桂孫（花押）
sen.e: Guarantor for the next 6 years: Keison (seal)
sen.cmt: 桂孫(Keison)の読み方が不明です。

Guarantor for the next 6 years: Keison (桂孫) (seal)

sen.j: 右近四郎（花押）
sen.e: Same as the above: Shiro UKON (seal)
Same as the above: Shiro UKON (seal)
Shiro UKON (seal)

sen.j: 13世紀中期ごろになると、農村社会に大きな変動が生じ始めた。
sen.e: Toward the middle of the 13th century, a far-reaching change started to occur in the rural society of Japan.
Toward the middle of the 13th century, a far-reaching change started to occur within rural society in Japan.
Toward the middle of the 13th century, a far-reaching change started to occur within rural society in Japan.

sen.j: 肥料や農具などの改善や米の品種改良の進展などを背景として、畿内や山陽などで二毛作が拡がるなど、農業生産が著しく向上していった。
sen.e: With the development of new fertilizers and agricultural tools, along with improvement in rice varieties, agricultural production increased remarkably as a result of various circumstances, such as the spread of double-cropping in Kinai and Sanyo regions.

With the development of new fertilizers and agricultural tools, along with the improvement of rice varieties through selective breeding, agricultural production increased remarkably as a result of various circumstances, such as the spread of double-cropping in Kinai and Sanyo regions.

With the development of new fertilizers and agricultural tools, along with the improvement of rice varieties through selective breeding, agricultural production increased remarkably as a result of various circumstances, such as the spread of double-cropping in Kinai and Sanyo regions.

sen.j: また、農業生産の向上は、手工業や広い範囲での流通を劇的に進展させ、さらに貨幣経済の普及をもたらすこととなった。
sen.e: An increase in agricultural production brought about not only dramatic progress in manual industry and commerce over a wide area but also the development of a monetary economy.
An increase in agricultural production brought about not only dramatic progress in manual industry and commerce over a wide area but also the development of a monetary economy.
An increase in agricultural production brought about not only dramatic progress in manual industry and commerce over a wide area but also the development of a monetary economy.

sen.j: こうした社会情勢の中で、従前、名主の支配・管理下で生産に従事していた一般百姓が経済力をつけていった。
sen.e: Under these social conditions, ordinary peasants, who had been engaged in farming under the rule and control of myoshu farmers, gradually gained economic power.
Under these social conditions, ordinary peasants, who had been engaged in farming under the rule and control of myoshu farmers, gradually gained economic power.
Under these social conditions, ordinary peasants, who had been engaged in farming under the rule and control of myoshu farmers, gradually gained economic power.

sen.j: 経済力を獲得した一般百姓は、名田を購入するなどし、名主の支配から次第に逃れていった。
sen.e: Having accumulated considerable wealth, these peasants purchased myoden and other properties, thereby gradually achieving freedom from the control of myoshu farmers.
Having accumulated considerable wealth, these peasants purchased myoden and other properties, thereby gradually achieving freedom from the control of myoshu farmers.
Having accumulated considerable wealth, these peasants purchased myoden and other properties, thereby gradually achieving freedom from the control of myoshu farmers.

sen.j: 中には、経済力を背景として国司・荘園領主から名主職に任じられて名主階層となる者もいた。
sen.e: Some of these peasants were even appointed as myoshu by territorial governors or manorial lords and became members of the myoshu class.
Some of these peasants were even appointed as myoshu by territorial governors or manorial lords and became members of the myoshu class.
Some of these peasants were even appointed as myoshu by territorial governors or manorial lords and became members of the myoshu class.

sen.j: 当時、名主職は相伝や譲与できる権利と認識されており、農村社会内部の均質化によって、名主の地位や権利は徐々に分割されていった。
sen.e: In this period, myoshu rights were already recognized as rights that could be inherited or sold, and as rural society became more and more homogenized, the position and rights of myoshu were split into smaller pieces.

In this period, myoshu rights were already recognized as rights that could be inherited or sold, and as rural society became more and more homogenized the position and rights of myoshu were split into smaller elements.

In this period, myoshu rights were already recognized as rights that could be inherited or sold, and as rural society became more and more homogenized the position and rights of myoshu were split into smaller elements.

sen.j: それまでは、名主職は代々相続される権利と認識されていたが、この頃から人々の間を移り変わる権利、すなわち遷代の職と認識されていったのである。
sen.e: In other words, myoshu rights, which had been inalienable and hereditary, were now regarded as being transferable or non-hereditary rights, whose ownership changed from one generation to the next.
In other words, myoshu rights, which had been inalienable and hereditary, were now regarded as being transferable or non-hereditary rights, whose ownership changed from one generation to the next.
In other words, myoshu rights, which had been inalienable and hereditary, were now regarded as being transferable or non-hereditary rights, whose ownership changed from one generation to the next.

sen.j: 名主は、分割化・遷代化の度合いを強める一方で、国司・荘園領主からの独立志向も強めていった。
sen.e: Myoshu farmers, whose rights were split into pieces and became non-hereditary, nevertheless became more and more independent of territorial governors and manorial lords during this period.
Myoshu farmers, whose rights were divided up and became non-hereditary, nevertheless became more and more independent of territorial governors and manorial lords during this period.
Myoshu farmers, whose rights were divided up and became non-hereditary, nevertheless became more and more independent of territorial governors and manorial lords during this period.

sen.j: 荘園・公領内部で、百姓階層の経済力向上と均質化が進んだことで、百姓階層は名主を中心に団結するようになった。
sen.e: As the farming class improved its economic status and became more homogenized, peasants learned to act in a body led by myoshu farmers.
As the farming class improved its economic status and became more homogenized, peasants learned to act together led by myoshu farmers.
As the farming class improved its economic status and became more homogenized, peasants learned to act together led by myoshu farmers.

sen.j: 荘園・公領に村落が発生したのは、13世紀後期から14世紀にかけての時期とされている。
sen.e: It is generally accepted that self-governing village communities were formed within manors and government territories in Japan from the late 13th to the early 14th century.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is generally accepted that self-governing village communities were formed within manors and government territories in Japan from the late 13th to the early 14th century.
It is generally accepted that self-governing village communities were formed within manors and government territories in Japan from the late 13th to the early 14th century.

sen.j: 百姓層の団結を背景として、国司・荘園領主に必ずしも従わない名主も現れた。
sen.e: Against the background of the solidarity among farmers, some myoshu farmers even refused to obey their rulers.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Against the background of the increasing solidarity among farmers, some myoshu farmers even refused to obey their rulers.
Against the background of the increasing solidarity among farmers, some myoshu farmers even refused to obey their rulers.

sen.j: 当時、悪党と呼ばれた者の中には、こうした名主も含まれていたと考えられている。
sen.e: It is believed that those who were called "villains" during this period may have included some of these disobedient myoshu farmers.
It is believed that those who were called "villains" during this period may have included some of these disobedient myoshu farmers.
It is believed that those who were called villains during this period may have included some of these disobedient myoshu farmers.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: 14世紀中期頃には、荘園・公領内の村落が自治性を高めるようになり、畿内や西国では惣村、東国や九州では郷村とよばれる自治村落へと成長していった。
sen.e: Around the middle of the 14th century, villages within manors and government territories increased their autonomy and grew into self-governing communities, which were called "soson" in Kinai and western regions and "goson" in eastern regions and Kyushu.

Around the middle of the 14th century, villages within manors and government territories increased their autonomy and grew into self-governing communities, which were called "soson" in Kinai and western regions and "goson" in eastern regions and Kyushu.

Around the middle of the 14th century, villages within manors and government territories increased their autonomy and grew into self-governing communities, which were called soson in Kinai and western regions and goson in eastern regions and Kyushu.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: そうなると名主の地位は相対的に低下することとなったが、名主は惣村・郷村の中で指導的な立場（乙名など）を務めるようになった。
sen.e: As a result, the relative status of myoshu lowered, causing myoshu farmers to assume roles as leaders (called "otona," etc.) in these village communities.
As a result, the relative status of myoshu declined, causing myoshu farmers to assume roles as leaders (with such titles as "otona") in these village communities.
As a result, the relative status of myoshu declined, causing myoshu farmers to assume roles as leaders (with such titles as otona) in these village communities.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: 室町時代、東国では荘園領主の権限がかなり小さくなっていたため、名主職の形骸化が激しく進んだ。
sen.e: During the Muromachi period, manorial lords lost much of their control in eastern regions, causing myoshu rights to deteriorate seriously.
During the Muromachi Period, manorial lords lost much of their control in eastern regions, causing myoshu rights to deteriorate considerably.
During the Muromachi period, manorial lords lost much of their control in eastern regions, causing myoshu rights to deteriorate considerably.

sen.j: しかし西国ではまだ荘園領主の権限が機能しており、名田単位による賦課が行われたため、名主の地位は残存し続けた。
sen.e: However, manorial lords maintained their control in western regions and continued to impose taxes based on the myoden system, thereby allowing myoshu to maintain their status.
However, manorial lords maintained their control in western regions and continued to impose taxes based on the myoden system, thereby allowing myoshu to maintain their status.
However, manorial lords maintained their control in western regions and continued to impose taxes based on the myoden system, thereby allowing myoshu to maintain their status.

sen.j: 室町期には守護による一円支配（守護領国制）が強まっていき、名主の権限は弱まっていった。
sen.e: During the Muromachi period, military governors of provinces called "shugo" gradually established control over different regions, thereby weakening the authority of myoshu.
During the Muromachi Period, military governors of provinces called "shugo" gradually established control over different regions, thereby weakening the authority of myoshu.
During the Muromachi period, shugo (military governors of provinces) gradually established control over different regions (known as shugo ryogoku system), thereby weakening the authority of myoshu.
sen.cmt: 補足し、かっこ内を英訳にしました。

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)に入ると、戦国大名による強固な領国支配（大名領国制）が布かれるようになり、一層、名主の権限は薄まっていった。
sen.e: During the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), daimyo (Japanese territorial lords) established absolute control over their regions, causing a further weakening of the authority of myoshu.
During the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), daimyo (Japanese territorial lords) established absolute control over their regions, causing a further weakening of the authority of myoshu.

During the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), daimyo (Japanese territorial lords) established absolute control over their regions (known as daimyo ryogoku system), causing a further weakening of the authority of myoshu.

sen.j: そして、太閤検地によって名主という地位・権限は実質的に消滅することとなる。
sen.e: And the land survey conducted by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI finally eliminated the position and authority of myoshu.
And finally the land survey conducted by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI resulted in the elimination of the position and authority of myoshu.
And finally the land survey conducted by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI resulted in the elimination of the position and authority of myoshu.

sen.j: しかし、室町期以来、村落自治が根付いていたこともあって、江戸幕府及び諸大名は、村落にある程度の自治を付与する民政を選択した。
sen.e: Nevertheless, due partly to the fact that self-government had already taken root in village communities, the Edo shogunate government and feudal lords chose to place villages under civil administration, allowing them a certain degree of self-government.

Nevertheless, due partly to the fact that self-government had already taken root in village communities, the Edo shogunate government and feudal lords chose to place villages under civil administration, allowing them a certain degree of self-government.

Nevertheless, due partly to the fact that self-government had already taken root in village communities, the Edo bakufu government and feudal lords chose to place villages under civil administration, allowing them a certain degree of self-government.

sen.j: 村落には指導的な立場として村役人・庄屋がおかれ、旧名主層がその役に就くことも多かった。
sen.e: There were positions of leaders in villages during the Edo period, called "murayakunin" (village officers) or "shoya" (village head), and these positions were often assumed by former myoshu.
Villages were given administrative leaders during the Edo Period, called "murayakunin" (village officers) or "shoya" (the village head), and these positions were often assumed by former myoshu.
Villages were given administrative leaders during the Edo period, called murayakunin (village officers) or shoya (the village head), and these positions were often assumed by former myoshu.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: 特に東日本では村落の指導的立場を名主と称する習わしが残り、多くの地域で村役人の筆頭が名主（なぬし）と呼ばれた。
sen.e: In many eastern regions, the custom of calling village heads "myoshu" persisted and the chief village officer was called "nanushi" in many of these regions.
In many eastern regions, the custom of calling village heads "myoshu" persisted and the chief village officer was called "nanushi" in many of these regions.
In many eastern regions, the custom of calling village heads myoshu persisted and the chief village officer was called nanushi in many of these regions.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを削除しました。
